Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Quantifying the Net Charge of Metalloproteins: a Fundamental but Elusive Property
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Bryan F. Shaw from Baylor University to use protein charge ladders to quantify the net charge of seven carefully chosen metalloproteins as a function of (i) metal stoichiometry, (ii) metal oxidation state, (iii) missense mutation, and (iv) pH. The results of this research are relevant for the fundamental understanding of the chemistry and catalysis of metalloprotein and they will help answer important questions such as: Does the net charge of a metalloprotein really contribute to the redox potential of its metal ion by ~ 23 mV per unit of charge? Do metalloproteins regulate net charge when cycling between oxidation states? To what degree will the cooperative network of ionizable groups in a metalloprotein allow it to regulate its net charge across pH, or in response to a missense mutation or the binding of a metal ion?
The net electrostatic charge of a metalloprotein is used to rationalize the rate and free energy change of a myriad of chemical processes, including electron transfer, molecular recognition, and self-assembly. However, the net charge of nearly all proteins has not been measured at any pH except for the pH at which the protein carries no net electrical charge because of the technical difficulty in making such measurements. The research funded by this award will enable the measurement of the net charge of the metalloproteins and consequently will advance our rigorous understanding of their chemistry. This award is also funding the work of Dr. Shaw's research group to develop tools that will help educators teach protein allostery to blind or visually-impaired students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goals of this project were to: (i) make the first direct measurements of the net charge (Z) of metalloproteins during metal binding and electron transfer, and (ii) develop new educational tools to help students with blindness or low vision (BLV) visualize the structure of metalloproteins. These goals have been reached. Using capillary zone electrophoresis and “protein charge ladders”, we have made the first direct measurements of how metalloproteins regulate their net electrostatic charge during metal loading and single electron transfer. Regarding single electron transfer, this project found that metalloproteins exhibit unique values of “charge regulation” (ΔZ) during electron transfer.  The copper protein azurin, for example, partially resisted changes in net charge upon single electron transfer, i.e., ΔZ = 0.51 units upon single electron transfer. Computational studies predicted that azurin’s ability to regulate charge upon electron transfer arises from long-range electrostatic interactions between copper and the side chains of multiple, non-coordinating residues, which alter the pKa of these side chains. The total change in free energy required for these = fluctuations in pKa can account for a large fraction of the reorganization energy previously measured for single electron transfer in azurin. In contrast, the iron-heme protein cytochrome c did not resist changes in net charge upon single electron transfer. Here, the transfer of a single electron altered the protein's net charge by ΔZ = 1.19 units. These unique values of ΔZ represent a new, easily measured parameter for electron transfer proteins. According to Marcus theory, these measured values of ΔZ can partially explain rates and redox potentials of electron transfer proteins. The findings of this study will have broad implications in understanding how proteins fine-tune the redox properties of electron transfer centers, in order to establish the reaction networks of life.

A separate part of this project quantified the net electrostatic charge of metalloproteins that bind multiple metal ions, and that misfold into amyloid fibrils. Experiments were carried out to quantify how a metalloprotein’s net charge is affected by: (i) amino acid substitution, (ii) coordination of multiple Cu(II), and Zn(II) ions, and (iii) changes in subcellular pH. We found that metalloproteins can tightly regulate net charge upon metal loading and large fluctuations in solvent pH. For example, the metalloprotein Cu, Zn superoxide dismutase (SOD1) tightly regulates its net charge upon changes in subcellular pH (i.e., ΔZ = ~ 3 units across pH 5-8, instead of the predicted value of ΔZ = ~ 14). These results will help understand how the SOD1 protein retains near diffusion-limited activity across subcellular pH. The results also help clarify the role that long-range electrostatic interactions play in the self-assembly of SOD1 into neurotoxic fibrils.

To make STEM more accessible to students with BLV, we invented and patented new tools to help students visualize protein structures using oral stereognosis (oral tactile sensing).  Here, we have converted publicly available protein structures (from the Protein Data Bank) into 3D models at millimeter scale. We are encouraging students to visualize the model by placing the model in their mouth (as opposed to visualization via manual tactile sensing with hands and fingers). These “mouth models”, which are fabricated in a food-safe environment, are intended to be used by BLV students of all ages and might be useful for students without BLV. Mouth models are intended to help grade school students with BLV see folded proteins for the first time, and to help older BLV students visualize the dynamic structure of allosteric proteins. Mouth models can be edible (made of the same material as “gummy bears”) or non-edible-biocompatible (3D printed, using a dental resin). In tests carried out on students from grade school to college, we have found that certain students can identify unique protein structures more accurately with oral tactile sensing than hand-based tactile sensing. The fabrication methods for edible “mouth models” are low cost and can be implemented by special needs educators working in any subject that utilizes graphical imagery or 3D pictures, across any field of science, engineering, math, business, law, or the humanities. These research activities were approved by an Institutional Review Board at Baylor University.


Last Modified: 06/20/2020
Modified by: Bryan Shaw
